The Plane of Fey is an innately magical domain teeming with flora that would enthuse even the most elitist horticulturist. In the aftermath of a battle, once all the useful knick knacks have been salvaged, the plants move in to feast on the rich, blood-soaked earth, sometimes waiting only a matter of days. Seeking roots can bind up broken weapons into clumps that, when properly harvested, can be sung into any formation.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Reroot. If you find a rootbound multiweapon, roll a [[/r d3]] and consult the table below to determine which type of weapon it is. As a bonus action, you can speak the weapon's command word, causing it to shift into another weapon of the same type.

A spiked cestus is a simple melee weapon worn around the knuckles of one hand that deals [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and has the Adaptable (piercing), Attached, and Pugilist properties.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.

Adaptable. This weapon can be used with differing techniques, allowing it to deal different types of damage. A damage type in parentheses appears with the property—when a creature makes a weapon attack with this weapon, it can choose either the weapon's normal damage type or this damage type.

Armour made from the cured bark of the xyxl tree is stronger and lighter than steel and possesses the ability to nourish its wearer. The source of the xyxl tree's immense durability is the mithral particles it incorporates into a rigid lattice throughout its wood. Scroll of Fungi (Uncommon).name: Scroll of Fungi (Uncommon)
Scroll of Fungi (Uncommon).description:
Scroll, uncommon

From morel to flycap, pixie's parasol to displacer's digestif, this magical vellum parchment sprouts an assortment of new mushrooms with each new dawn. Its true power, however, is in summoning magic mushrooms. To those without knowledge of the required languages, the letters on the scroll shift and move, seemingly without meaning.

Fungal Conjuration. If you can read Druidic, Elvish, Sylvan, or Undercommon, you can use an action while holding this scroll to speak the script aloud and summon one of the following mushrooms of your choice, which appears in your hand. As part of this action, you can use the mushroom as described below. The summoned mushroom withers and dies after 1 hour. Once this property of the scroll has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

  • Boomshroom. As an action, a creature can throw this volatile mushroom at a point it can see within 60 feet of it, where it explodes in a 10-foot-radius sphere of flames. Each creature in the area must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking [[/r 4d6]] fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

  • Bloomshroom. As an action, a creature can eat this mushroom, regaining [[/r 2d4 + 2]] hit points and gaining advantage on Constitution saving throws for 1 minute.

  • Gloomshroom. As an action, a creature can eat this mushroom. For 1 hour, it gains darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. If it already has darkvision, the range of this vision is increased by 30 feet.

In the aftermath of a battle, once all the useful knick knacks have been salvaged, the plants move in to feast on the rich, blood-soaked earth, sometimes waiting only a matter of days. Seeking roots can bind up broken weapons into clumps that, when properly harvested, can be sung into any formation.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Reroot. If you find a rootbound multiweapon, roll a [[/r d3]] and consult the table below to determine which type of weapon it is. As a bonus action, you can speak the weapon's command word, causing it to shift into another weapon of the same type.

Nunchuks are martial melee weapons composed of two hard batons, usually wood or metal, connected to one another by a short chain. They have the versatile (1d8), finesse, and special (flourish) properties, and deal 1d6 bludgeoning damage on a hit.

Special: Flourish. When you are wielding the nunchaku in two hands and take the Attack action on your turn, you can attempt to flourish with the weapon immediately before you make your first attack. To flourish, make a DC 13 Dexterity check, adding your proficiency bonus if you are proficient with nunchaku. On a success, you gain a +2 bonus to the first attack roll you make this turn. On a failure, you deal bludgeoning damage to yourself equal to your proficiency bonus and gain no bonus from your flourishes this turn.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Waspberry Jam (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon

This terracotta jar, 4 inches in diameter, contains [[/r 1d4 + 1]] doses of a sweet, sticky, pink jam. The jar and its contents weigh ½ pound.

Insect Trap. As an action, you can spread a single dose of jam to cover a 5-foot-square surface. Tiny, venomous waspberries immediately teleport from the Plane of Fey, forming a @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.S0zDrv6lbnwWaz9E]{Swarm of Insects} that stays in the same spot as the jam and takes its turn on initiative count 0 of each round. The swarm attacks the closest creature to it that is within 15 feet of the jam's space, and otherwise takes the Dodge action. A creature that starts its turn in the swarm's area or enters the area for the first time on its turn must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw, taking [[/r 1d4]] piercing damage and [[/r 1d4]] poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the swarm has half its hit points or fewer, creatures instead take [[/r 1d4]] piercing damage and [[/r 1d4]] poison damage.

It takes the swarm 1 hour to completely consume the jam, after which it returns to the Plane of Fey. The swarm doesn't like smoke; if the area where the jam is applied is ever heavily obscured by smoke, the swarm teleports back to the Plane of Fey. If the smoke disappears, the swarm immediately returns to continue eating the jam.

Scroll of Fungi (Rare).name: Scroll of Fungi (Rare)
Scroll of Fungi (Rare).description:
Scroll, rare

From morel to flycap, pixie's parasol to displacer's digestif, this magical vellum parchment sprouts an assortment of new mushrooms with each new dawn. Its true power, however, is in summoning magic mushrooms. To those without knowledge of the required languages, the letters on the scroll shift and move, seemingly without meaning.

Fungal Conjuration. If you can read Druidic, Elvish, Sylvan, or Undercommon, you can use an action while holding this scroll to speak the script aloud and summon one of the following mushrooms of your choice, which appears in your hand. As part of this action, you can use the mushroom as described below. The summoned mushroom withers and dies after 1 hour. Once this property of the scroll has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

  • Boomshroom. As an action, a creature can throw this volatile mushroom at a point it can see within 60 feet of it, where it explodes in a 10-foot-radius sphere of flames. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking [[/r 8d6]] fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

  • Bloomshroom. As an action, a creature can eat this mushroom, regaining [[/r 4d4 + 4]] hit points and gaining advantage on Constitution saving throws for 1 minute.

  • Gloomshroom. As an action, a creature can eat this mushroom. For 1 hour, it gains darkvision out to a range of 90 feet. If it already has darkvision, the range of this vision is increased by 45 feet.

Scroll, very rare

From morel to flycap, pixie's parasol to displacer's digestif, this magical vellum parchment sprouts an assortment of new mushrooms with each new dawn. Its true power, however, is in summoning magic mushrooms. To those without knowledge of the required languages, the letters on the scroll shift and move, seemingly without meaning.

Fungal Conjuration. If you can read Druidic, Elvish, Sylvan, or Undercommon, you can use an action while holding this scroll to speak the script aloud and summon one of the following mushrooms of your choice, which appears in your hand. As part of this action, you can use the mushroom as described below. The summoned mushroom withers and dies after 1 hour. Once this property of the scroll has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

  • Boomshroom. As an action, a creature can throw this volatile mushroom at a point it can see within 60 feet of it, where it explodes in a 10-foot-radius sphere of flames. Each creature in the area must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw, taking [[/r 12d6]] fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

  • Bloomshroom. As an action, a creature can eat this mushroom, regaining [[/r 8d4 + 8]] hit points and gaining advantage on Constitution saving throws for 1 minute.

  • Gloomshroom. As an action, a creature can eat this mushroom. For 1 hour, it gains darkvision out to a range of 120 feet. If it already has darkvision, the range of this vision is increased by 60 feet. A creature that eats the Gloomshroom can see invisible creatures and objects in the range of its darkvision as if they were visible.

A tetherhook is a martial melee weapon with the Reach, Two-handed, and Special: Hookpull properties. It is comprised of a hook attached to a chain or strap and deals [[/r 1d8]] piercing damage on a hit.

Special: Hookpull. As a bonus action immediately after you hit a target no more than one size larger than you with an attack using the tetherhook, you can attempt to hook the target using the tetherhook’s reach. Make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target’s Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you succeed, the target is hooked and can’t move further away from you. A hooked creature is no longer hooked if you release the tether with both hands, but only one hand is required to keep a creature hooked. A hooked creature can use its action to escape. To do so, it must succeed on a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by your Strength (Athletics) check.

As part of the bonus action to hook the target, and as a bonus action on any of your subsequent turns while it remains hooked, you can pull the target 5 feet closer to you, as long as it isn’t fixed in place and it weighs less than your push, drag, or lift capacity.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

A spiked cestus is a simple melee weapon worn around the knuckles of one hand that deals [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and has the Adaptable (piercing), Attached, and Pugilist properties.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.
